head.title: From a Nuclear Power Plant, Alarm and Inspiration

hedline.hl1: From a Nuclear Power Plant, Alarm and Inspiration

abstract.p: Group show opens at One Station Plaza in Peekskill, NY, offering artists' views of radioactive leak at Indian Point Nuclear Plant 2; photos (M)

block.p: THE official alert may be over, but alarm over the radioactive leak at the Indian Point Nuclear Plant 2 earlier this year continues to reverberate through the Hudson Valley.
Fourteen artists share their impressions of the plant in ''Letting Off Steam,'' a group show at One Station Plaza, a performance space and gallery in Peekskill. (Information: 736-1053).
THE official alert may be over, but alarm over the radioactive leak at the Indian Point Nuclear Plant 2 earlier this year continues to reverberate through the Hudson Valley.
Fourteen artists share their impressions of the plant in ''Letting Off Steam,'' a group show at One Station Plaza, a performance space and gallery in Peekskill. (Information: 736-1053).

The show, which continues through May 21, includes, at far left, ''Chances'' by Julie Chase, which was created from pieces of wood found along the banks of the Hudson River. (The plant, below, is situated by the river near Buchanan.)
Above from left: ''Everything Is Fine,'' a ceramic work by Dina Bursztyn; ''Ground Zero'' by Georgia Svolos, ''Protect Our Children'' by Ilse Schreiber-Noll and ''Death Valley'' by Coulter Young.
Another perspective was offered by Anthony Acciaro in a poem, excerpted here, which he read at a reception for the artists last month:
Our dreams have all been burned
